glossary.definition: A set of rules or instructions designed to solve a problem or complete a task.
A system of numerical notation that uses two symbols, typically 0 and 1.
A temporary storage area used to speed up data retrieval processes.
An organized collection of structured information stored electronically.
The process of converting information into a code to prevent unauthorized access.
A security system that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic.
A device or software that acts as a bridge between two networks with different protocols.
A process of transforming data into a fixed-size string of characters, usually for security purposes.
A shared boundary across which two systems exchange information.
A programming language commonly used for web development to create interactive elements.
The central part of an operating system responsible for managing hardware resources.
The delay before a transfer of data begins following an instruction for its transfer.
Data that provides information about other data, such as creation date or file size.
A group of interconnected computers or devices that share resources and information.
A programming paradigm based on objects containing both data and methods.
A set of rules governing communication between devices in a network.
A request for data or information from a database.
A device that forwards data packets between computer networks.
A computer system that provides services or resources to other computers over a network.
The process of breaking down text into smaller units like words or phrases.
A universal character encoding standard supporting most written languages.
An emulation of a computer system that runs programs like a physical machine.
A method of augmenting or altering the behavior of web applications through custom callbacks.
A markup language designed to store and transport structured data.
A human-readable data serialization format often used for configuration files.
A cyberattack targeting a previously unknown vulnerability in software.
Application Programming Interface; a set of rules allowing programs to communicate with each other.
A distributed ledger technology where transactions are recorded chronologically and publicly.
The delivery of computing services over the internet without direct management by the user.
Domain Name System; translates domain names into IP addresses.
A distributed computing paradigm bringing computation closer to the data source.
Software embedded into hardware devices to control their functionality.
A version control system used to track changes in source code during software development.
A reference to data that readers can directly follow by clicking or tapping.
Integrated Development Environment; software for building applications combining tools in one GUI.
JavaScript Object Notation; a lightweight data-interchange format.
An open-source container orchestration platform automating deployment and scaling of apps.
A device or software distributing incoming network traffic across multiple servers.
An architectural style structuring an app as loosely coupled services.
A runtime environment enabling server-side execution of JavaScript.
Software whose source code is freely available for modification and redistribution.
Acts as an intermediary between clients and servers to filter requests or cache responses.
A type of computing leveraging quantum mechanics to perform complex calculations faster.
An API adhering to Representational State Transfer principles for stateless client-server interactions.
A malicious attack injecting SQL queries via input fields to manipulate databases.
A sequence of instructions executed independently within a program.
Uniform Resource Locator; the address used to access resources on the internet.
A system managing changes to documents, programs, and other collections of information.
Wireless networking technology allowing devices to connect to the internet wirelessly.
Cross-Site Scripting; a security vulnerability injecting malicious scripts into trusted websites.
A unit of digital information equal to 1 septillion bytes (10^24).
A wireless communication protocol for low-power, short-range connectivity.
